title.raw: 《田儋列傳》 Biography of Tian Dan

sentences.zh: 田儋者，狄人也，故齊王田氏族也。

translations.literal: Tian Dan was from Di, an ancient clan of the Qi kings.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Dan hailed from Di and belonged to the ancient royal clan of Qi.

sentences.zh: 儋從弟田榮，榮弟田橫，皆豪，宗彊，能得人。

translations.literal: Dan's younger brothers Tian Rong and Tian Heng were both heroes, their clan was powerful, they could attract followers.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Dan's younger brothers Tian Rong and Tian Heng were both heroic figures. Their clan wielded great influence and could rally many supporters.

translations.literal: Tian Dan hailed from Di and belonged to the ancient royal clan of Qi. Tian Dan's younger brothers Tian Rong and Tian Heng were both heroic figures. Their clan wielded great influence and could rally many supporters.

sentences.zh: 陳涉之初起王楚也，使周市略定魏地，北至狄，狄城守。

translations.literal: When Chen She first rose and declared himself king of Chu, he sent Zhou Shi to conquer Wei territory, reaching north to Di, where Di resisted.
translations.idiomatic: When Chen She first rose up and proclaimed himself King of Chu, he dispatched Zhou Shi to secure Wei territory. Zhou Shi pushed north as far as Di, where the city held out against him.

sentences.zh: 田儋詳為縛其奴，從少年之廷，欲謁殺奴。

translations.literal: Tian Dan pretended to bind his slave, followed the young men to court, wanting to petition to kill the slave.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Dan feigned binding his slave and, accompanied by a group of young men, went to the court, intending to petition for the slave's execution.

sentences.zh: 見狄令，因擊殺令，而召豪吏子弟曰：「諸侯皆反秦自立，齊，古之建國，儋，田氏，當王。」

translations.literal: Seeing the magistrate of Di, he struck and killed him, then summoned the sons of powerful officials saying: The feudal lords have all rebelled against Qin and established themselves, Qi is an ancient established state, I Tian Dan of the Tian clan should be king.
translations.idiomatic: Upon seeing the magistrate of Di, he attacked and killed him, then gathered the sons of influential officials and declared: All the feudal lords have risen against Qin and proclaimed their own kingdoms. Qi is an ancient realm with deep roots, and I, Tian Dan of the Tian clan, am destined to rule it.

sentences.zh: 遂自立為齊王，發兵以擊周市。

translations.literal: Thus he established himself as King of Qi, and sent troops to attack Zhou Shi.
translations.idiomatic: Thus he proclaimed himself King of Qi and dispatched troops to attack Zhou Shi.

sentences.zh: 周市軍還去，田儋因率兵東略定齊地。

translations.literal: Zhou Shi's army retreated and left, Tian Dan then led troops east to conquer Qi territory.
translations.idiomatic: Zhou Shi's forces withdrew, allowing Tian Dan to lead his troops eastward and secure control over Qi lands.

translations.literal: When Chen She first rose up and proclaimed himself King of Chu, he dispatched Zhou Shi to secure Wei territory. Zhou Shi pushed north as far as Di, where the city held out against him. Tian Dan feigned binding his slave and, accompanied by a group of young men, went to the court, intending to petition for the slave's execution. Upon seeing the magistrate of Di, he attacked and killed him, then gathered the sons of influential officials and declared: All the feudal lords have risen against Qin and proclaimed their own kingdoms. Qi is an ancient realm with deep roots, and I, Tian Dan of the Tian clan, am destined to rule it. Thus he proclaimed himself King of Qi and dispatched troops to attack Zhou Shi. Zhou Shi's forces withdrew, allowing Tian Dan to lead his troops eastward and secure control over Qi lands.

sentences.zh: 秦將章邯圍魏王咎於臨濟，急。

translations.literal: Qin general Zhang Han besieged Wei King Jiao at Linji, the situation was urgent.
translations.idiomatic: Qin general Zhang Han laid siege to King Jiao of Wei at Linji, creating a dire emergency.

sentences.zh: 魏王請救於齊，齊王田儋將兵救魏。

translations.literal: Wei King requested aid from Qi, Qi King Tian Dan led troops to rescue Wei.
translations.idiomatic: King Jiao of Wei appealed to Qi for help, and King Tian Dan of Qi marched troops to Wei's rescue.

sentences.zh: 章邯夜銜枚擊，大破齊、魏軍，殺田儋於臨濟下。

translations.literal: Zhang Han at night attacked with gags in mouths, greatly defeating Qi and Wei armies, killing Tian Dan below Linji.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Han launched a surprise night attack, his soldiers silent with gags, routing the combined Qi and Wei forces and slaying Tian Dan beneath the walls of Linji.

sentences.zh: 儋弟田榮收儋餘兵東走東阿。

translations.literal: Tian Rong was the younger brother of King Tian Dan of Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Rong was the younger brother of King Tian Dan of Qi.

translations.literal: Qin general Zhang Han laid siege to King Jiao of Wei at Linji, creating a dire emergency. King Jiao of Wei appealed to Qi for help, and King Tian Dan of Qi marched troops to Wei's rescue. Zhang Han launched a surprise night attack, his soldiers silent with gags, routing the combined Qi and Wei forces and slaying Tian Dan beneath the walls of Linji. Tian Rong was the younger brother of King Tian Dan of Qi.

sentences.zh: 田榮之走東阿，章邯追圍之。

translations.literal: After Dan's death, Rong installed Dan's son Tian Shi as king. He then attacked westward, killing Zhou Shi at Qian, and drove Zhang Han's army back from Linji, eventually proclaiming himself king.
translations.idiomatic: After Dan's death, Rong installed Dan's son Tian Shi as king. He then attacked westward, killing Zhou Shi at Qian, and drove Zhang Han's army back from Linji, eventually proclaiming himself king.

sentences.zh: 項梁聞田榮之急，乃引兵擊破章邯軍東阿下。

translations.literal: When Zhang Han fled in defeat, King Rong of Qi remained at Xingyang, where Zhang Han besieged the city.
translations.idiomatic: When Zhang Han fled in defeat, King Rong of Qi remained at Xingyang, where Zhang Han besieged the city.

sentences.zh: 章邯走而西，項梁因追之。

translations.literal: Rong appealed to Chu general Xiang Liang for help. Xiang Liang came to Qi's aid, defeated Zhang Han's forces at Linji, and drove them back.
translations.idiomatic: Rong appealed to Chu general Xiang Liang for help. Xiang Liang came to Qi's aid, defeated Zhang Han's forces at Linji, and drove them back.

sentences.zh: 而田榮怒齊之立假，乃引兵歸，擊逐齊王假。

translations.literal: Zhang Han eventually fled back to Zhao, and King Rong of Qi led his troops eastward in retreat.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Han eventually fled back to Zhao, and King Rong of Qi led his troops eastward in retreat.

sentences.zh: 假亡走楚。

translations.literal: After Xiang Liang's death in battle, Zhang Han regained his strength and marched against Zhao, inflicting a major defeat.
translations.idiomatic: After Xiang Liang's death in battle, Zhang Han regained his strength and marched against Zhao, inflicting a major defeat.

sentences.zh: 齊相角亡走趙；

translations.literal: King Rong of Qi grew angry and said, Chu killed Tian Jia but still sent troops to help them—that's not righteous!
translations.idiomatic: King Rong of Qi grew angry and said, Chu killed Tian Jia but still sent troops to help them—that's not righteous!

sentences.zh: 角弟田閒前求救趙，因留不敢歸。

translations.literal: He therefore refused to aid Zhao and instead attacked Zhang Han's forces, dealing them a crushing defeat.
translations.idiomatic: He therefore refused to aid Zhao and instead attacked Zhang Han's forces, dealing them a crushing defeat.

sentences.zh: 田榮乃立田儋子市為齊王。

translations.literal: Zhang Han fled with his troops, and King Rong pursued him northward to the Pu River, where he killed Zhang Han.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Han fled with his troops, and King Rong pursued him northward to the Pu River, where he killed Zhang Han.

sentences.zh: 榮相之，田橫為將，平齊地。

translations.literal: Yan general Zang Tu also raised troops to attack Zhao, motivated by the case of Yan Dan.
translations.idiomatic: Yan general Zang Tu also raised troops to attack Zhao, motivated by the case of Yan Dan.

translations.literal: After Dan's death, Rong installed Dan's son Tian Shi as king. He then attacked westward, killing Zhou Shi at Qian, and drove Zhang Han's army back from Linji, eventually proclaiming himself king. When Zhang Han fled in defeat, King Rong of Qi remained at Xingyang, where Zhang Han besieged the city. Rong appealed to Chu general Xiang Liang for help. Xiang Liang came to Qi's aid, defeated Zhang Han's forces at Linji, and drove them back. Zhang Han eventually fled back to Zhao, and King Rong of Qi led his troops eastward in retreat. After Xiang Liang's death in battle, Zhang Han regained his strength and marched against Zhao, inflicting a major defeat. King Rong of Qi grew angry and said, Chu killed Tian Jia but still sent troops to help them—that's not righteous! He therefore refused to aid Zhao and instead attacked Zhang Han's forces, dealing them a crushing defeat. Zhang Han fled with his troops, and King Rong pursued him northward to the Pu River, where he killed Zhang Han. Yan general Zang Tu also raised troops to attack Zhao, motivated by the case of Yan Dan.

sentences.zh: 項梁既追章邯，章邯兵益盛，項梁使使告趙、齊，發兵共擊章邯。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu commanded forces numbering several tens of thousands, claiming a million, and camped at Julu, where he confronted Zhang Han's army.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu commanded forces numbering several tens of thousands, claiming a million, and camped at Julu, where he confronted Zhang Han's army.

sentences.zh: 田榮曰：「使楚殺田假，趙殺田角、田閒，閒肯出兵。」

translations.literal: Yan general Zang Tu attacked Zhang Han's forces, but Zhang Han launched a surprise night attack with gagged soldiers, routing the Yan army.
translations.idiomatic: Yan general Zang Tu attacked Zhang Han's forces, but Zhang Han launched a surprise night attack with gagged soldiers, routing the Yan army.

sentences.zh: 楚懷王曰：「田假與國之王，窮而歸我，殺之不義。」

translations.literal: Zang Tu fled to Chu, where King Chu settled him in Pengcheng.
translations.idiomatic: Zang Tu fled to Chu, where King Chu settled him in Pengcheng.

sentences.zh: 趙亦不殺田角、田閒以市於齊。

translations.literal: When King Rong of Qi learned of Xiang Yu's death and that all the other feudal lords had surrendered, he alone refused to submit.
translations.idiomatic: When King Rong of Qi learned of Xiang Yu's death and that all the other feudal lords had surrendered, he alone refused to submit.

sentences.zh: 齊曰：「蝮螫手則斬手，螫足則斬足。

translations.literal: Han King Liu Bang dispatched Peng Yue's troops to besiege him at Chengyang.
translations.idiomatic: Han King Liu Bang dispatched Peng Yue's troops to besiege him at Chengyang.

sentences.zh: 何者？

translations.literal: Rong led his troops eastward to defend Yingqiu, pursued by Han general Guan Ying.
translations.idiomatic: Rong led his troops eastward to defend Yingqiu, pursued by Han general Guan Ying.

sentences.zh: 為害於身也。

translations.literal: Rong's army suffered repeated defeats, with heavy casualties among his soldiers.
translations.idiomatic: Rong's army suffered repeated defeats, with heavy casualties among his soldiers.

sentences.zh: 今田假、田角、田閒於楚、趙，非直手足戚也，何故不殺？

translations.literal: Rong then sent envoys bearing valuable gifts to bribe King Zang Tu of Yan, urging him to attack Han Xin.
translations.idiomatic: Rong then sent envoys bearing valuable gifts to bribe King Zang Tu of Yan, urging him to attack Han Xin.

sentences.zh: 且秦復得志於天下，則齮龁用事者墳墓矣。」

translations.literal: King Zang Tu of Yan attacked Han Xin at the Wei River and dealt him a major defeat.
translations.idiomatic: King Zang Tu of Yan attacked Han Xin at the Wei River and dealt him a major defeat.

sentences.zh: 楚、趙不聽，齊亦怒，終不肯出兵。

translations.literal: When Han King Liu Bang learned of this, he sent Chancellor Cao Can to defeat King Zang Tu at Aocang. Zang Tu fled and was killed.
translations.idiomatic: When Han King Liu Bang learned of this, he sent Chancellor Cao Can to defeat King Zang Tu at Aocang. Zang Tu fled and was killed.

sentences.zh: 章邯果敗殺項梁，破楚兵，楚兵東走，而章邯渡河圍趙於鉅鹿。

translations.literal: King Rong of Qi then fled eastward to defend Jimo.
translations.idiomatic: King Rong of Qi then fled eastward to defend Jimo.

sentences.zh: 項羽往救趙，由此怨田榮。

translations.literal: Guan Ying attacked King Rong at Qiansheng and routed him.
translations.idiomatic: Guan Ying attacked King Rong at Qiansheng and routed him.

translations.literal: Xiang Yu commanded forces numbering several tens of thousands, claiming a million, and camped at Julu, where he confronted Zhang Han's army. Yan general Zang Tu attacked Zhang Han's forces, but Zhang Han launched a surprise night attack with gagged soldiers, routing the Yan army. Zang Tu fled to Chu, where King Chu settled him in Pengcheng. When King Rong of Qi learned of Xiang Yu's death and that all the other feudal lords had surrendered, he alone refused to submit. Han King Liu Bang dispatched Peng Yue's troops to besiege him at Chengyang. Rong led his troops eastward to defend Yingqiu, pursued by Han general Guan Ying. Rong's army suffered repeated defeats, with heavy casualties among his soldiers. Rong then sent envoys bearing valuable gifts to bribe King Zang Tu of Yan, urging him to attack Han Xin. King Zang Tu of Yan attacked Han Xin at the Wei River and dealt him a major defeat. When Han King Liu Bang learned of this, he sent Chancellor Cao Can to defeat King Zang Tu at Aocang. Zang Tu fled and was killed. King Rong of Qi then fled eastward to defend Jimo. Guan Ying attacked King Rong at Qiansheng and routed him.

sentences.zh: 項羽既存趙，降章邯等，西屠咸陽，滅秦而立侯王也，乃徙齊王田市更王膠東，治即墨。

translations.literal: Rong retreated to defend Yingqiu, where Guan Ying besieged him.
translations.idiomatic: Rong retreated to defend Yingqiu, where Guan Ying besieged him.

sentences.zh: 齊將田都從共救趙，因入關，故立都為齊王，治臨淄。

translations.literal: Rong's younger brother Tian Heng rallied the scattered Qi troops, gathering several tens of thousands, and attacked Guan Ying's forces, dealing them a major defeat.
translations.idiomatic: Rong's younger brother Tian Heng rallied the scattered Qi troops, gathering several tens of thousands, and attacked Guan Ying's forces, dealing them a major defeat.

sentences.zh: 故齊王建孫田安，項羽方渡河救趙，田安下濟北數城，引兵降項羽，項羽立田安為濟北王，治博陽。

translations.literal: Guan Ying besieged Yingqiu, forcing Rong to flee to Donglai. Guan Ying caught up with Rong at Qiansheng and killed him.
translations.idiomatic: Guan Ying besieged Yingqiu, forcing Rong to flee to Donglai. Guan Ying caught up with Rong at Qiansheng and killed him.

sentences.zh: 田榮以負項梁不肯出兵助楚、趙攻秦，故不得王；

translations.literal: Guan Ying attacked Donglai, but the defending general held the city and refused to surrender.
translations.idiomatic: Guan Ying attacked Donglai, but the defending general held the city and refused to surrender.

sentences.zh: 趙將陳餘亦失職，不得王：二人俱怨項王。

translations.literal: When Han King Liu Bang learned of King Rong's death, he flew into a rage and issued an order: The people of Qi are fickle, a nation of traitors! They border Chu to the south.
translations.idiomatic: When Han King Liu Bang learned of King Rong's death, he flew into a rage and issued an order: The people of Qi are fickle, a nation of traitors! They border Chu to the south.

translations.literal: Rong retreated to defend Yingqiu, where Guan Ying besieged him. Rong's younger brother Tian Heng rallied the scattered Qi troops, gathering several tens of thousands, and attacked Guan Ying's forces, dealing them a major defeat. Guan Ying besieged Yingqiu, forcing Rong to flee to Donglai. Guan Ying caught up with Rong at Qiansheng and killed him. Guan Ying attacked Donglai, but the defending general held the city and refused to surrender. When Han King Liu Bang learned of King Rong's death, he flew into a rage and issued an order: The people of Qi are fickle, a nation of traitors! They border Chu to the south.

sentences.zh: 頊王既歸，諸侯各就國，田榮使人將兵助陳餘，令反趙地，而榮亦發兵以距擊田都，田都亡走楚。

translations.literal: He did not want Qi people to follow their king and therefore ordered the territory to be divided among the nobility, with Lu as the boundary.
translations.idiomatic: He did not want Qi people to follow their king and therefore ordered the territory to be divided among the nobility, with Lu as the boundary.

sentences.zh: 田榮留齊王市，無令之膠東。

translations.literal: He dispatched Grand General Han Xin to attack Qi.
translations.idiomatic: He dispatched Grand General Han Xin to attack Qi.

sentences.zh: 市之左右曰：「項王彊暴，而王當之膠東，不就國，必危。」

translations.literal: Han Xin led troops eastward to attack Qi. King Heng defended the cities but surrendered without battle, allowing Han Xin to pacify all Qi territory.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin led troops eastward to attack Qi. King Heng defended the cities but surrendered without battle, allowing Han Xin to pacify all Qi territory.

sentences.zh: 市懼，乃亡就國。

translations.literal: After Xiang Yu's death, Han King Liu Bang used Peng Yue's troops to besiege King Tian Heng of Qi at Chengyang, forcing Heng to surrender to Peng Yue.
translations.idiomatic: After Xiang Yu's death, Han King Liu Bang used Peng Yue's troops to besiege King Tian Heng of Qi at Chengyang, forcing Heng to surrender to Peng Yue.

sentences.zh: 田榮怒，追擊殺齊王市於即墨，還攻殺濟北王安。

translations.literal: Peng Yue entrusted Heng to Marquis Yue of Lean, making him a military advisor and settling him in Yang.
translations.idiomatic: Peng Yue entrusted Heng to Marquis Yue of Lean, making him a military advisor and settling him in Yang.

sentences.zh: 於是田榮乃自立為齊王，盡并三齊之地。

translations.literal: Heng and two of his retainers sailed into the sea and took refuge on an island.
translations.idiomatic: Heng and two of his retainers sailed into the sea and took refuge on an island.

translations.literal: He did not want Qi people to follow their king and therefore ordered the territory to be divided among the nobility, with Lu as the boundary. He dispatched Grand General Han Xin to attack Qi. Han Xin led troops eastward to attack Qi. King Heng defended the cities but surrendered without battle, allowing Han Xin to pacify all Qi territory. After Xiang Yu's death, Han King Liu Bang used Peng Yue's troops to besiege King Tian Heng of Qi at Chengyang, forcing Heng to surrender to Peng Yue. Peng Yue entrusted Heng to Marquis Yue of Lean, making him a military advisor and settling him in Yang. Heng and two of his retainers sailed into the sea and took refuge on an island.

sentences.zh: 項王聞之，大怒，乃北伐齊。

translations.literal: When Gaozu learned of this, he grew furious and said, Tian Heng and his followers admire righteousness and dwell on an island, making me appear resentful to all under heaven.
translations.idiomatic: When Gaozu learned of this, he grew furious and said, Tian Heng and his followers admire righteousness and dwell on an island, making me appear resentful to all under heaven.

sentences.zh: 齊王田榮兵敗，走平原，平原人殺榮。

translations.literal: He sent envoys bearing imperial credentials to summon Heng. Heng and his two retainers traveled by relay carriage to Luoyang.
translations.idiomatic: He sent envoys bearing imperial credentials to summon Heng. Heng and his two retainers traveled by relay carriage to Luoyang.

sentences.zh: 項王遂燒夷齊城郭，所過者盡屠之。

translations.literal: Before reaching Luoyang, thirty li away, they arrived at the pavilion of the Marquis of Shixiang.
translations.idiomatic: Before reaching Luoyang, thirty li away, they arrived at the pavilion of the Marquis of Shixiang.

sentences.zh: 齊人相聚畔之。

translations.literal: Heng addressed the envoys: As a subject about to see the emperor, I must bathe and purify myself.
translations.idiomatic: Heng addressed the envoys: As a subject about to see the emperor, I must bathe and purify myself.

sentences.zh: 榮弟橫，收齊散兵，得數萬人，反擊項羽於城陽。

translations.literal: He told his retainers: I once sat facing south as king alongside the Han King, both calling ourselves sovereign. Now the Han King is emperor, and I am reduced to a fugitive serving him facing north—what humiliation!
translations.idiomatic: He told his retainers: I once sat facing south as king alongside the Han King, both calling ourselves sovereign. Now the Han King is emperor, and I am reduced to a fugitive serving him facing north—what humiliation!

sentences.zh: 而漢王率諸侯敗楚，入彭城。

translations.literal: He then cut his own throat and ordered his retainers to present his head to the envoys, who rushed to deliver it to the emperor.
translations.idiomatic: He then cut his own throat and ordered his retainers to present his head to the envoys, who rushed to deliver it to the emperor.

sentences.zh: 項羽聞之，乃醳齊而歸，擊漢於彭城，因連與漢戰，相距滎陽。

translations.literal: Gaozu exclaimed, Alas! There was reason for it!
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu exclaimed, Alas! There was reason for it!

sentences.zh: 以故田橫復得收齊城邑，立田榮子廣為齊王，而橫相之，專國政，政無巨細皆斷於相。

translations.literal: Gaozu pardoned Heng's retainers, ordering them to live in Luoyang.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu pardoned Heng's retainers, ordering them to live in Luoyang.

translations.literal: When Gaozu learned of this, he grew furious and said, Tian Heng and his followers admire righteousness and dwell on an island, making me appear resentful to all under heaven. He sent envoys bearing imperial credentials to summon Heng. Heng and his two retainers traveled by relay carriage to Luoyang. Before reaching Luoyang, thirty li away, they arrived at the pavilion of the Marquis of Shixiang. Heng addressed the envoys: As a subject about to see the emperor, I must bathe and purify myself. He told his retainers: I once sat facing south as king alongside the Han King, both calling ourselves sovereign. Now the Han King is emperor, and I am reduced to a fugitive serving him facing north—what humiliation! He then cut his own throat and ordered his retainers to present his head to the envoys, who rushed to deliver it to the emperor. Gaozu exclaimed, Alas! There was reason for it! Gaozu pardoned Heng's retainers, ordering them to live in Luoyang.

sentences.zh: 橫定齊三年，漢王使酈生往說下齊王廣及其相國橫。

translations.literal: Tian Heng's two retainers, fearing that the emperor would eventually kill them, buried themselves alive in Heng's tomb.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Heng's two retainers, fearing that the emperor would eventually kill them, buried themselves alive in Heng's tomb.

sentences.zh: 橫以為然，解其歷下軍。

translations.literal: Gaozu heard of this and praised them greatly, saying, There are no more men like these two!
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu heard of this and praised them greatly, saying, There are no more men like these two!

sentences.zh: 漢將韓信引兵且東擊齊。

translations.literal: He bestowed upon their families ten households each to support them.
translations.idiomatic: He bestowed upon their families ten households each to support them.

sentences.zh: 齊初使華無傷、田解軍於歷下以距漢，漢使至，乃罷守戰備，縱酒，且遣使與漢平。

translations.literal: Fan Kuai was from Pei, a subordinate of Gaozu.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Kuai was from Pei, a subordinate of Gaozu.

sentences.zh: 漢將韓信已平趙、燕，用蒯通計，度平原，襲破齊歷下軍，因入臨淄。

translations.literal: He had once saved Gaozu's life when they were surrounded by Xiang Yu's troops at Xingyang.
translations.idiomatic: He had once saved Gaozu's life when they were surrounded by Xiang Yu's troops at Xingyang.

sentences.zh: 齊王廣、相橫怒，以酈生賣己，而亨酈生。

translations.literal: Gaozu became emperor and enfeoffed Kuai as Marquis of Ye.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu became emperor and enfeoffed Kuai as Marquis of Ye.

sentences.zh: 齊王廣東走高密，相橫走博（陽），守相田光走城陽，將軍田既軍於膠東。

translations.literal: Li Shang was from Chengyang, a Chu man.
translations.idiomatic: Li Shang was from Chengyang, a Chu man.

sentences.zh: 楚使龍且救齊，齊王與合軍高密。

translations.literal: He served under Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu, later submitting to Han.
translations.idiomatic: He served under Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu, later submitting to Han.

sentences.zh: 漢將韓信與曹參破殺龍且，虜齊王廣。

translations.literal: He followed Han Xin in attacking Yan and Zhao, establishing merit.
translations.idiomatic: He followed Han Xin in attacking Yan and Zhao, establishing merit.

sentences.zh: 漢將灌嬰追得齊守相田光。

translations.literal: Gaozu enfeoffed him as Marquis of Quyang.
translations.idiomatic: Gaozu enfeoffed him as Marquis of Quyang.

sentences.zh: 至博（陽），而橫聞齊王死，自立為齊王，還擊嬰，嬰敗橫之軍於嬴下。

translations.literal: Teng Ying was from Jingling, a Chu man.
translations.idiomatic: Teng Ying was from Jingling, a Chu man.

sentences.zh: 田橫亡走梁，歸彭越。

translations.literal: He was a Confucian scholar who had studied under Fuqiu Bo.
translations.idiomatic: He was a Confucian scholar who had studied under Fuqiu Bo.

sentences.zh: 彭越是時居梁地，中立，且為漢，且為楚。

translations.literal: He served as an official under Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu.
translations.idiomatic: He served as an official under Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu.

sentences.zh: 韓信已殺龍且，因令曹參進兵破殺田既於膠東，使灌嬰破殺齊將田吸於千乘。

translations.literal: When Xiang Yu perished, Ying submitted to Han.
translations.idiomatic: When Xiang Yu perished, Ying submitted to Han.

sentences.zh: 韓信遂平齊，乞自立為齊假王，漢因而立之。

translations.literal: He became a clerk for Han Xin, following him in pacifying Yan.
translations.idiomatic: He became a clerk for Han Xin, following him in pacifying Yan.

translations.literal: Tian Heng's two retainers, fearing that the emperor would eventually kill them, buried themselves alive in Heng's tomb. Gaozu heard of this and praised them greatly, saying, There are no more men like these two! He bestowed upon their families ten households each to support them. Fan Kuai was from Pei, a subordinate of Gaozu. He had once saved Gaozu's life when they were surrounded by Xiang Yu's troops at Xingyang. Gaozu became emperor and enfeoffed Kuai as Marquis of Ye. Li Shang was from Chengyang, a Chu man. He served under Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu, later submitting to Han. He followed Han Xin in attacking Yan and Zhao, establishing merit. Gaozu enfeoffed him as Marquis of Quyang. Teng Ying was from Jingling, a Chu man. He was a Confucian scholar who had studied under Fuqiu Bo. He served as an official under Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu. When Xiang Yu perished, Ying submitted to Han. He became a clerk for Han Xin, following him in pacifying Yan.

sentences.zh: 後歲餘，漢滅項籍，漢王立為皇帝，以彭越為梁王。

translations.literal: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Dingtao.
translations.idiomatic: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Dingtao.

sentences.zh: 田橫懼誅，而與其徒屬五百餘人入海，居島中。

translations.literal: Guan Ying was from Donghai.
translations.idiomatic: Guan Ying was from Donghai.

sentences.zh: 高帝聞之，以為田橫兄弟本定齊，齊人賢者多附焉，今在海中不收，後恐為亂，乃使使赦田橫罪而召之。

translations.literal: He served Gaozu as a cavalry officer.
translations.idiomatic: He served Gaozu as a cavalry officer.

sentences.zh: 田橫因謝曰：「臣亨陛下之使酈生，今聞其弟酈商為漢將而賢，臣恐懼，不敢奉詔，請為庶人，守海島中。」

translations.literal: He participated in the battle of Pengcheng, where he was wounded.
translations.idiomatic: He participated in the battle of Pengcheng, where he was wounded.

sentences.zh: 使還報，高皇帝乃詔衛尉酈商曰：「齊王田橫即至，人馬從者敢動搖者致族夷！」

translations.literal: He followed Gaozu to Guanzhong, establishing merit.
translations.idiomatic: He followed Gaozu to Guanzhong, establishing merit.

sentences.zh: 乃復使使持節具告以詔商狀，曰：「田橫來，大者王，小者乃侯耳；

translations.literal: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Yishui.
translations.idiomatic: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Yishui.

sentences.zh: 不來，且舉兵加誅焉。」

translations.literal: He died in the first year of Gaozu's reign.
translations.idiomatic: He died in the first year of Gaozu's reign.

sentences.zh: 田橫乃與其客二人乘傳詣雒陽。

translations.literal: Guan Ying's son Guan Fu succeeded him as marquis.
translations.idiomatic: Guan Ying's son Guan Fu succeeded him as marquis.

translations.literal: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Dingtao. Guan Ying was from Donghai. He served Gaozu as a cavalry officer. He participated in the battle of Pengcheng, where he was wounded. He followed Gaozu to Guanzhong, establishing merit. He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Yishui. He died in the first year of Gaozu's reign. Guan Ying's son Guan Fu succeeded him as marquis.

sentences.zh: 未至三十里，至尸鄉廄置，橫謝使者曰：「人臣見天子當洗沐。」

translations.literal: Lu Jia was from Zhuxu, a Chu man.
translations.idiomatic: Lu Jia was from Zhuxu, a Chu man.

sentences.zh: 止留。

translations.literal: He had been a traveling merchant.
translations.idiomatic: He had been a traveling merchant.

sentences.zh: 謂其客曰：「橫始與漢王俱南面稱孤，今漢王為天子，而橫乃為亡虜而北面事之，其恥固已甚矣。

translations.literal: He advised Gaozu on governing the realm.
translations.idiomatic: He advised Gaozu on governing the realm.

sentences.zh: 且吾亨人之兄，與其弟并肩而事其主，縱彼畏天子之詔，不敢動我，我獨不愧於心乎？

translations.literal: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Shen.
translations.idiomatic: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Shen.

sentences.zh: 且陛下所以欲見我者，不過欲一見吾面貌耳。

translations.literal: He composed the Spring and Autumn Annals of the New Era.
translations.idiomatic: He composed the Spring and Autumn Annals of the New Era.

sentences.zh: 今陛下在洛陽，今斬吾頭，馳三十里閒，形容尚未能敗，猶可觀也。」

translations.literal: Zhou Chang was from Pei, a subordinate of Gaozu.
translations.idiomatic: Zhou Chang was from Pei, a subordinate of Gaozu.

sentences.zh: 遂自剄，令客奉其頭，從使者馳奏之高帝。

translations.literal: He participated in the battle of Pengcheng, where he was wounded.
translations.idiomatic: He participated in the battle of Pengcheng, where he was wounded.

sentences.zh: 高帝曰：「嗟乎，有以也夫！

translations.literal: He followed Gaozu to Guanzhong, establishing merit.
translations.idiomatic: He followed Gaozu to Guanzhong, establishing merit.

sentences.zh: 起自布衣，兄弟三人更王，豈不賢乎哉！」

translations.literal: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Dingyang.
translations.idiomatic: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Dingyang.

sentences.zh: 為之流涕，而拜其二客為都尉，發卒二千人，以王者禮葬田橫。

translations.literal: Ding Che was from Pei, a subordinate of Gaozu.
translations.idiomatic: Ding Che was from Pei, a subordinate of Gaozu.

translations.literal: Lu Jia was from Zhuxu, a Chu man. He had been a traveling merchant. He advised Gaozu on governing the realm. He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Shen. He composed the Spring and Autumn Annals of the New Era. Zhou Chang was from Pei, a subordinate of Gaozu. He participated in the battle of Pengcheng, where he was wounded. He followed Gaozu to Guanzhong, establishing merit. He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Dingyang. Ding Che was from Pei, a subordinate of Gaozu.

sentences.zh: 既葬，二客穿其冢旁孔，皆自剄，下從之。

translations.literal: He participated in the battle of Pengcheng, where he was wounded.
translations.idiomatic: He participated in the battle of Pengcheng, where he was wounded.

sentences.zh: 高帝聞之，乃大驚，大田橫之客皆賢。

translations.literal: He followed Gaozu to Guanzhong, establishing merit.
translations.idiomatic: He followed Gaozu to Guanzhong, establishing merit.

sentences.zh: 吾聞其餘尚五百人在海中，使使召之。

translations.literal: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Nangong.
translations.idiomatic: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Nangong.

sentences.zh: 至則聞田橫死，亦皆自殺。

translations.literal: Liu Ze was from Pei, Gaozu's nephew.
translations.idiomatic: Liu Ze was from Pei, Gaozu's nephew.

sentences.zh: 於是乃知田橫兄弟能得士也。

translations.literal: He participated in the battle of Pengcheng, where he was wounded.
translations.idiomatic: He participated in the battle of Pengcheng, where he was wounded.

translations.literal: He participated in the battle of Pengcheng, where he was wounded. He followed Gaozu to Guanzhong, establishing merit. He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Nangong. Liu Ze was from Pei, Gaozu's nephew. He participated in the battle of Pengcheng, where he was wounded.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：甚矣蒯通之謀，亂齊驕淮陰，其卒亡此兩人！

translations.literal: He followed Gaozu to Guanzhong, establishing merit.
translations.idiomatic: He followed Gaozu to Guanzhong, establishing merit.

sentences.zh: 蒯通者，善為長短說，論戰國之權變，為八十一首。

translations.literal: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Chengyang.
translations.idiomatic: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Chengyang.

sentences.zh: 通善齊人安期生，安期生嘗干項羽，項羽不能用其筴。

translations.literal: Shen Yiji was from Lu, a Chu man.
translations.idiomatic: Shen Yiji was from Lu, a Chu man.

sentences.zh: 已而項羽欲封此兩人，兩人終不肯受，亡去。

translations.literal: He served under Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu.
translations.idiomatic: He served under Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu.

sentences.zh: 田橫之高節，賓客慕義而從橫死，豈非至賢！

translations.literal: When Xiang Yu perished, he submitted to Han.
translations.idiomatic: When Xiang Yu perished, he submitted to Han.

sentences.zh: 余因而列焉。

translations.literal: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Huaiyin.
translations.idiomatic: He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Huaiyin.

sentences.zh: 不無善畫者，莫能圖，何哉？

translations.literal: Wang Wu was from Pei, a subordinate of Gaozu.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Wu was from Pei, a subordinate of Gaozu.

translations.literal: He followed Gaozu to Guanzhong, establishing merit. He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Chengyang. Shen Yiji was from Lu, a Chu man. He served under Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu. When Xiang Yu perished, he submitted to Han. He was enfeoffed as Marquis of Huaiyin. Wang Wu was from Pei, a subordinate of Gaozu.
